page.title: 01INTRODUCTION
page.content: THIS AREA, NEATLY BISECTED BY THE RIVER EDEN, CONSISTS OF THE TWIN PARISHES OF NATEBY AND WHARTON. THEY LIE IN A RELATIVELY ISOLATED AND COMPLETELY UNSPOILT AREA BOUNDED ON THE WEST BY THE CARLISLE-SETTLE RAILWAY AND ALMOST REACHING THE YORKSHIRE BORDER ON THE EAST. NATEBY IS A SMALL COMPACT VILLAGE WHEREAS WHARTON IS A HAMLET OF SCATTERED FAMILY FARMS.THE WHOLE AREA IS A FARMING COMMUNITY AND ITS ECONOMIC STRUCTURE DEPENDS MAINLY ON SHEEP REARING. THE GREATER PART IS OPEN FELL LAND WITH LIMESTONE OUTCROPS, DRY- STONE WALLED FIELDS WITH TRADITIONAL STONE FIELD HOUSES COVER THE LOWER PART OF THE VALLEY.THE HIGHEST POINT IS 1518 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL AND THE AREA IS EXPOSED TO THE PREVAILING SOUTH WEST WINDS.IN SEVERE WINTERS SNOW SOMETIMES BLOCKS THE ROADS.
